awd_titl_txt: Near Threshold Excited State Dynamics in Nucleobases and Related Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. de Vries at the University of California Santa Barbara will study how isolated DNA bases respond to ultraviolet (UV) light. Understanding the response of DNA bases to UV radiation is critical for both practical and fundamental reasons. Nucleobase photochemistry following UV absorption constitutes a fundamental step in radiation induced DNA damage. The extremely efficient response of the nucleobases to absorption of ultraviolet light is often described as nature's strategy to protect the building blocks of life against UV photodamage. UV photo-selection may have played a key role in prebiotic chemistry on an early earth. These same processes also find applications in a variety of modern materials. 

This project will focus on gas phase spectroscopy of nucleobases and their clusters in the picosecond time domain and close to the threshold for absorption. Experiments will study the excited state processes with the isomer specificity afforded by double resonant spectroscopy in the gas phase and in the sub-nanosecond time domain. Collaboration with computational chemists will provide comparison of the results with quantum chemical modeling. Choosing low energy excitation wavelengths will make the work most sensitive to the details of the relaxation processes. This approach will make it possible to directly investigate the key mechanisms of the response of nucleobases to UV irradiation so this research will contribute to the most basic understanding of fundamental processes that govern the molecular building blocks of life. These topics, in combination with cutting-edge laser and computational techniques, lend themselves extraordinary well to outreach activities that will be based in this work, which also provides for the training of both undergraduate and graduate students in the design and construction of advanced experimental instrumentation, complex computer simulation, and conducting fundamental research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award abstract

In this project has studied how isolated DNA bases and related compounds respond to ultraviolet (UV) light. Understanding the response of these molecules to UV radiation is critical for both practical and fundamental reasons. Nucleobase photochemistry following UV absorption constitutes a fundamental step in radiation induced DNA damage. Similar photochemistry causes colors to fade in works of art, affecting the world?s cultural heritage. The extremely efficient response of the canonical nucleobases, (the bases that make up DNA), to absorption of ultraviolet light is often described as nature?s strategy to protect the building blocks of life against UV photodamage. UV photo-selection may have played a key role in prebiotic chemistry on an early earth, which led to the origin of life. These same processes also find applications in a variety of modern materials.

This fundamental photochemistry has been the focus of this project, which revealed details of the response to UV radiation at a time scale of picoseconds (a millionth of a millionth of a second). The work shows in great detail why the canonical bases are more photostable than so-called alternative bases. The latter are bases that would likely have been present in a primordial soup as alternative building blocks of life. Given the harsh UV radiation on the early earth, this difference in UV hardiness could help explain natures choice of the components of our DNA. Alternative bases, studied in in this project, include isoguanine, diaminopurine and xanthine.

Similar photochemistry governs the fate of priceless works of art. Pigments have to absorb light in order to have color. Pigments that are unable to safely handle such absorption are prone to fading. This project elucidated why indigo is among the most stable pigments and why certain madder lake reds are still brightly visible on classical paintings while other shades of colorants from the same molecular family in the same painting are fatally faded.

These topics, in combination with cutting-edge laser and computational techniques, lend themselves extraordinary well to outreach activities, based in this work, which also provided for the training of both undergraduate and graduate students in the design and construction of advanced experimental instrumentation, complex computer simulation, and conducting fundamental research.
